questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E3 subscription.

You plan to audit all Microsoft Exchange Online user and admin activities.

You need to ensure that all the Exchange audit log records are retained for one year.

What should you do?

choices.C: Create a custom audit retention policy.
choices.D: Assign Microsoft 365 Enterprise E5 licenses to all users.
choices.A: Modify the record type of the default audit retention policy.
choices.B: Modify the retention period of the default audit retention policy.

discussion.content: Correct, E3 only allows for 90 days

Audit (Premium) in Microsoft Purview provides a default audit log retention policy for all organizations. This policy can't be modified and retains all Exchange Online, SharePoint, OneDrive, and Microsoft Entra audit records for one year.

The default audit log retention policy only applies to audit records for activity performed by users who are assigned an Office 365 or Microsoft 365 E5 license or have a Microsoft 365 E5 Compliance or E5 eDiscovery and Audit add-on license. If you have non-E5 users or guest users in your organization, their corresponding audit records are retained for 180 days.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/audit-log-retention-policies?tabs=microsoft-purview-portal#default-audit-log-retention-policy

Selected Answer: D
Both C and D are correct but the E5 license is a requirement if you want to audit more than 180 days.
There's a particular mention on D, it says "all users" but only the user who creates the policy need a E5 license, on the other hand there is no evidence that this user has a E5 assigned so I go to D.

Selected Answer: D
E3 cannot provide 1 year retention, need E5 or addons

Selected Answer: C
ChatGPT says C ... I agree that E5 is needed, but will it do it on its own?

Wrong, Microsoft 365 already has the confidential information type "Credit Card Number", so it is not necessary to create a new one. Correct sequence:

1- Create a Sensitivity label
2- Crate an auto-labeling policy
3- Wait 24 hours and then turn on the policy (from the simulation mode).

comments.content: Agree There is already a SIT for Credit card
agree but there is no need to wait 24h before turning on the policy, it doesn't make any different to turn it on right away.

discussion.content:
Little Hint: It takes up to 24 hours for the auto-labeling policy to replicate throughout your organization.

with love
Got this question on exam on 17th August

Should be the following based on link below (see how simulation is required and takes at least 12 hours; only auto-turns on if ignored for 7 days):
1 - Create sensitivity label
2 - Create auto-labeling policy (requires sim mode before enabling)
3 - Wait 24 hours and then turn on (after sim mode runs)
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/apply-sensitivity-label-automatically?view=o365-worldwide#how-to-configure-auto-labeling-policies-for-sharepoint-onedrive-and-exchange

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You need to meet the technical requirements for the Site1 documents.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains the users shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You review the audit retention period of each user.

Which users' audit logs are retained for nine months?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
See the overview of information below as generated by ChatGPT

Microsoft 365 E3 (User1):

Audit log retention: 90 days (default).
With Advanced Audit (part of E5 or added-on to E3), it extends to 1 year or custom up to 10 years.
Microsoft 365 F3 (User2):

Audit log retention: 90 days.
F3 users are not eligible for Advanced Audit capabilities.
Microsoft 365 E5 (User3):

Audit log retention: 9 months (default) due to Advanced Audit being included.
Can be extended to custom periods (e.g., 1 year, up to 10 years) if configured.

comments.content:
edit: 
With no mention of advanced audit, only User3 is correct
The audit log retention period in Microsoft 365 varies based on the license assigned to a user. Here's the breakdown:

Microsoft 365 E3 (User1):

Audit log retention: 90 days (default).
With Advanced Audit (part of E5 or added-on to E3), it extends to 1 year or custom up to 10 years.
Microsoft 365 F3 (User2):

Audit log retention: 90 days.
F3 users are not eligible for Advanced Audit capabilities.
Microsoft 365 E5 (User3):

Audit log retention: 9 months (default) due to Advanced Audit being included.
Can be extended to custom periods (e.g., 1 year, up to 10 years) if configured.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains a user named User1.

User1 plans to export a history of Microsoft Purview communication compliance policy changes.

You need to add User1 to a role group in Microsoft Purview. The solution must follow the principle of least privilege.

To which role group should you add User1?

You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.

You are evaluating whether to use the Microsoft Purview auditing solutions shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You plan to implement Microsoft Purview Audit (Standard).

Which solutions can you use?
